pr_title: [GSoC] Add `Developer options` category
pr_body:
## Purpose / Description
Move options exclusive to debug builds to its own category from the bottom of advanced category. 

## Approach
1. Create a XML layout with the previous debug options
2. Extract the debug options from the advanced category to the new one

## How Has This Been Tested?

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/171644357-8adf8cf9-bd03-4f4d-b124-ffcb66fd3286.mp4

pr_title: [GSoC] Reorganize reviewing preferences
pr_body:
## Approach
1. Move `New time zone handling` and `Double tap time` to a subcategory called `Advanced`
2. Rename `behavior` subcategory to `scheduling`
3. Remove Whiteboard stroke width preference
4. Create a new subcategory called `Accessibility` on Appearance and move some of the reviewing preferences there
5. Create a new subcategory called `Reviewer` on Appearance and move some of the reviewing preferences there
6. Build Reviewing category from other strings


https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/174076398-4c62ad02-a4a0-4dc7-bcbb-13d951e68d25.mp4

pr_title: [GSoC] Refactor preferences action bar title configuration
pr_body:
## Purpose / Description
DRY on preferences fragments titles and YAGNI on SpecificSettingsFragment.setTitle

## Approach
- Get the fragment title from the PreferenceScreen instead of setting them manually
- Add the corresponding titles to the fragments without a title
- Remove SpecificSettingsFragment.setTitle since it isn't necessary now, and I believe that is a YAGNI case

## How Has This Been Tested?

Emulator on SDK 25 (the video shows the actionbar getting updated on screen changes)

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/172668515-da2b655a-e7bd-467d-a251-790191b9c01a.mp4

pr_title: [GSoC] Fix sync button color
pr_body:
## Purpose / Description
If user changed themes, the sync icon would use the same color of the sync category icon

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/174460604-60f8fb7b-58ae-4641-9ccd-55e89a59fc40.png)


## Approach
Make sync icon inherit its color from `iconColor` attribute and set it to white on the top bar style.

More work could be done to untangle some icons from their colors and use styles to tint them instead of doing it programatically (e.g. on the reviewer app bar actions). I currently don't have time to untangle all the XMLs and icons, which should be a fair amount of work, but I particularly see it as an valid issue.

## How Has This Been Tested?

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/174460499-e9d40a31-b445-41e6-b32f-45bd0d16c515.mp4

## Learning (optional, can help others)
TIL that setting the tint of an icon on code is a global change which will be shown if an activity is recreated.

pr_title: [GSoC] Add a search bar to the settings screen
pr_body:
## Pull Request template

## Purpose / Description
_Describe the problem or feature and motivation_

## Fixes
Fixes #8342

## Approach
- refactored some things to ease the search bar code
1. Add [SearchPreference](https://github.com/ByteHamster/SearchPreference) library
    - MIT licensed
    - I've contacted the author to question about the lack of updates for ~1 year:
        > Hi, Nice to hear that you want to integrate my library. There is not much development going on because it just works. It is integrated into AntennaPod and K-9 Mail and I have not heard of crashes or bugs there, so there is no need to commit anything :) If I get critical bug reports, I do plan to fix the problems. ByteHamster
     - edit: I had to send some PRs and they were accepted fairly quickly, so we can conclude that the mantainer is stil active
2. Implement the search bar
    - Add SearchPreferenceResultListener to the activty with the search bar
    - Add the search bar to the fragment which will hold it (HeaderFragment)
    - Configure the search index
        - Index the preferences XMLs
        - Ignore some preferences based on some conditions
        - Index the preferences that are created programatically (i.e. are not on a XML)
    - Set the resultClicked action
3. Add a test

## How Has This Been Tested?

![WhatsApp Image 2022-07-05 at 11 08 47](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/177347550-a77f663b-93bd-433a-bc15-d65b88506f9e.jpeg)

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/177347590-957c4c2b-3dd0-4821-b9b1-f04cb2c60444.mp4

## Learning (optional, can help others)

[SearchPreference](https://github.com/ByteHamster/SearchPreference)

## Checklist
_Please, go through these checks before submitting the PR._

- [X] You have not changed whitespace unnecessarily (it makes diffs hard to read)
- [X] You have a descriptive commit message with a short title (first line, max 50 chars).
- [X] Your code follows the style of the project (e.g. never omit braces in `if` statements)

pr_title: [GSoC] Create a new about category
pr_body:
## Approach
- Stop using the old webView one
- Create a new Android layout
- Add an icon and top category for it
- Factorize some methods related to developer options
- Enable developer options on release builds under a secret

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/178154676-4ec5af18-e268-4fb1-a6cf-bad35be12f7c.png)


## How Has This Been Tested?

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/178156689-bb3676de-c574-47ea-ae65-017a871ef08b.mp4

## Checklist
_Please, go through these checks before submitting the PR._

- [X] You have not changed whitespace unnecessarily (it makes diffs hard to read)
- [X] You have a descriptive commit message with a short title (first line, max 50 chars).
- [X] Your code follows the style of the project (e.g. never omit braces in `if` statements) 
- [X] You have commented your code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas
- [X] You have performed a self-review of your own code
- [X] UI changes: include screenshots of all affected screens (in particular showing any new or changed strings)
- [ ] UI Changes: You have tested your change using the [Google Accessibility Scanner](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.google.android.apps.accessibility.auditor)

Would you mind maybe adding a small word in the commit message for each deleted file, that'd help review", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 10, 19, 55, 55, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 917445370, 'comment_body': 'Probably a conscious decision to not use the `@string`, but it would work (albeit showing `$1` and HTML)', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 10, 20, 53, 24, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'david-allison', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 917445665, 'comment_body': 'These are unused and would cause a lint failure', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 10, 20, 56, 10, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'david-allison', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 917445770, 'comment_body': 'Note that this is a functional change, as we no longer allow it to be enabled', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 10, 20, 57, 22, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'david-allison', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 917446156, 'comment_body': 'These settings are dangerous (will probably break the app or corrupt the collection). 

I really think we should also have a message box here.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 10, 21, 1, 40, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'david-allison', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 917451017, 'comment_body': "> Probably a conscious decision to not use the @string, but it would work

yep

> (albeit showing $1 and HTML)

Here's the reason. XML preview looked quite bad and the text would change on runtime anyway, so I used `tools:text` to have a better XML preview. I think that's fine?", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 10, 21, 50, 53, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 917451081, 'comment_body': "I beg your pardon but I haven't got what you mean here. Is this a note or something I should change?", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 10, 21, 51, 50, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 917451173, 'comment_body': "I don't understand why. I'd be curious if you could explain", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 10, 21, 52, 45, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 917453127, 'comment_body': 'Fixed. Thanks!', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 10, 22, 11, 44, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 917453818, 'comment_body': "üëçüèª Added it on the first commit message.

> Remove `InfoTestNoOnCreate.kt` because it was only used to check if the app wouldn't crash while building the HTML string for the old about screen", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 10, 22, 19, 31, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 917453958, 'comment_body': 'I'm not against the extra safety. Besides the it being hidden and the current dangerous options already having a message saying somethink like this ("These settings are dangerous (will probably break the app or corrupt the collection").

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/178164073-69e1f26d-06e7-42c9-9f3b-a0560b4e12fd.png)

I'll push it soon', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 10, 22, 21, 36, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 917456265, 'comment_body': "It's a note that the second commit drops functionality, which is added back in the third commit. Optional if you want to action this since we won't squash the commits. If you don't, mark as resolved ", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 10, 22, 41, 10, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'david-allison', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 917456496, 'comment_body': '> I don't understand why. I'd be curious if you could explain

One of the options is literally "lock the database and don't release the lock". 
We also give users the new anki schema, which has the potential to corrupt collection. 
No users should be using any of the settings.

I would not be opposed to adding a "corrupt this collection" option here in future.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 10, 22, 43, 39, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'david-allison', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 917456544, 'comment_body': "It is, as long as it's a conscious decision.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 10, 22, 44, 20, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'david-allison', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 917465506, 'comment_body': 'Oh, now I get it. Fixed, thanks.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 10, 23, 59, 35, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 918395958, 'comment_body': 'I personally don't like this level of indentation. It requires lot of reading to understand that it is "what occurs if you have clicked clickLimit time on the about app, then have seen the material dialog shown, then click on okay.

I would have a strong preference to split this in two methods, or at least one. This can even more easily be done because the only information in common in all methods is the context.
One method can be what occurs when we "ok". One other method would be in charge of showing the material dialog.

There are two distinct reasons for my preferences. First, because as a reviewer, I'd find it easier to consider separately: "is `ok` doing what I want", "is the dialog as I want" and "is the dialog show function called at the right time". 
Also, if at some point we actually want to really test it, it'll be far easier. For example, we can use a mock to check that if we click `clickLimit` time, the method to show the dialog is called.

Same remarks applies to `setOnPreferenceChangeListener` above for example.


I know that this is not consistent with an important part of our current codebase. But honestly, I'd consider that it'd be something to change for cleaning and clarity purpose, not something to imitate', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 11, 22, 23, 36, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 921511697, 'comment_body': 'Wildcard imports can be avoided, though this is not a blocker for PR merge.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 14, 19, 42, 40, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'ShridharGoel', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 921690661, 'comment_body': 'I agree. Although this one was added automatically by the IDE.

Default for Kotlin is 3 imports to substitute to `*` (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49870306/disable-wild-cart-import-in-intellij-android-studio-in-kotlin)

It can be a good first issue to change it on the project codestyle file (https://github.com/ankidroid/Anki-Android/blob/main/.idea/codeStyles/Project.xml)', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 14, 23, 28, 48, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 921692061, 'comment_body': "Another possible issue is to create a lint rule (or maybe there is one we can activate, or maybe isn't necessary after the codestyle file is modified) to avoid wildcard imports on the codebase.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 14, 23, 32, 31, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 921695977, 'comment_body': "I'll resolve the comment as I think this is a thing that could be enforced automatically", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 14, 23, 43, 33, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 922768394, 'comment_body': 'Curiosity: Why not use a single layout file for the about fragment?', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 17, 4, 33, 6, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lukstbit', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 922768642, 'comment_body': 'Do you plan to extract this string? Seems weird to have it in the file where all strings are preferences keys.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 17, 4, 37, 54, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lukstbit', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 922812610, 'comment_body': "It smells like a race condition waiting to occurs. With two successive click, leading to line 125 `clickCount += 1` executed twice and then equality checked twice and both time false. 
I don't think it's actually possible, as, to my understanding, `onClick` executes in foreground, so no race here. 
Still, I'd feel more safe with 
`if (++clickCount == clickLimit)`

if not, at least a comment explaining why, even if the class is stateful, and not synchronized, no race condition can occur here
", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 17, 10, 47, 53, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 922812833, 'comment_body': 'There was a comment on both layouts explaining why.
Basically, for some reason, if I wrap the base layout with a `ScrollView` directly, the Android Studio preview becomes worse.

While I tried to reproduce it to take a screenshot, Idk what I did different but the preview looks fine, so I joined them on the last commit, thanks!
', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 17, 10, 49, 22, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 922812990, 'comment_body': "> Do you plan to extract this string? Seems weird to have it in the file where all strings are preferences keys.

Nope. But I agree that's a little weird. I added a comment on the last commit to help.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 17, 10, 50, 38, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 922817204, 'comment_body': '```
<!--
Messages displayed after the user enabled developer options, and warned remaining messages will be in English.
-->
```', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 17, 11, 24, 4, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 922828317, 'comment_body': 'Really liked it. Thanks. Amended it on the last commit.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 17, 12, 45, 53, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 922828428, 'comment_body': 'Amended it on the last commit.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 17, 12, 46, 38, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}]

pr_title: [GSoC] Refactor preferences initialization
pr_body:
~~On top of #11866. I should rebase once that is merged.~~

## Purpose / Description

Preferences initialization was a bit messy. Every screen ran [initAllPreferences](https://github.com/ankidroid/Anki-Android/blob/abd1f8bfc316cdf11aba51af7bda7f5b05c493d7/AnkiDroid/src/main/java/com/ichi2/anki/Preferences.kt#L205) and [initPreference](https://github.com/ankidroid/Anki-Android/blob/abd1f8bfc316cdf11aba51af7bda7f5b05c493d7/AnkiDroid/src/main/java/com/ichi2/anki/Preferences.kt#L225) multiple times, making things quite hard to follow. 

To keep things tidy, concise, and keep the preferences' configuration responsability on themselves and on their screens, I've done some refactors on the preferences activity

## Approach

1. Extract the preferences initialization to their screens on the `Init X preference individually` commits
- The required changes that escape the previous 2 patterns are marked on the commits as a `**` on the message beginning and are described as well

## How Has This Been Tested?

Manually opened/changed all preferences and it still works correctly. I should upload a video of it later.

## Checklist
_Please, go through these checks before submitting the PR._

- [X] You have not changed whitespace unnecessarily (it makes diffs hard to read)
- [X] You have a descriptive commit message with a short title (first line, max 50 chars).
- [X] Your code follows the style of the project (e.g. never omit braces in `if` statements) 
- [X] You have commented your code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas
- [X] You have performed a self-review of your own code
- [ ] UI changes: include screenshots of all affected screens (in particular showing any new or changed strings)
- [ ] UI Changes: You have tested your change using the [Google Accessibility Scanner](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.google.android.apps.accessibility.auditor)

"It didn't anything else" I think it misses a verb.

Technically, it did at least one change. It ensured that even if listener rejected, the value would be saved. 

I'd appreciate if you could add a note to indicate whether you looked at git blame to check what was the point of the introduction. You may have heard of "Chesterton's fence": knowing why something was before removing it.

It was introduced in 93c02a5c61a1a17d5d6176fec01a2266f87ce643 by @david-allison (who reviewed, so I trust if there was an issue he may have detected it) quoting https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5533078/timepicker-in-preferencescreen/34398747#34398747 and #5019

I see no comment explaining why we should ignore listener's so I'm probably fine with deleting it. I just would appreciate if the commit message could state that this change was investigated, how the investigation was done, and that we concluded there was no reason not to use default here', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 17, 22, 35, 28, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 922905930, 'comment_body': "I am convinced that the behavior is not changed, but it took the assumption that setting `isEnabled` to true when the version is greater than one is acceptable.
It is, because by default, enabled is true. 
This can be found by looking at the implementation of Preference. It does not seems to be documented in https://developer.android.com/reference/kotlin/androidx/preference/Preference#setenabled 
In any case, it's clearly better to explicitly set it in all case than to use a non-documented default in one case, so I believe this change is an improvement.

However, I admit that I'd have preferred to be able to read about this research and not have to do it myself to check the behavior is exactly the same
", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 17, 22, 54, 33, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 922906515, 'comment_body': 'Note for any future reviewer. The meaning of "enabled" here is different from the one in the new code. Here it is whether "new timezone" is enabled. There it is whether the toggle button is enabled', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 17, 23, 0, 16, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 922907899, 'comment_body': 'I'd appreciate if, instead of "newValue", you could have a more descriptive such as `enableNewTimeZoneHandling`.  It would ensure a reader (me) needs less context to understand this part of the code.

Same remark for other commit, but I find it especially important when the code is not trivial', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 17, 23, 13, 39, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 922908400, 'comment_body': "I assume this conditional was changed because  while `onSharedPreferenceChanged` documentation state that it can actually be called when no change occur (and so, we needed to ensure that we don't enable it multiple time), the `PreferenceChangeListener` documentation seems to imply that it'll be called only on change.

In the worst case, a useless call will just call `setMod` and lead AnkiDroid to believes falsely a sync is needed, so no big deal. And since we don't protect against it in the other cases, there is no reason to protect against it here.

I think it would be more easily discoverable this way.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 18, 22, 53, 39, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 923923886, 'comment_body': 'Does anyone have a corrupted collection for me to reproduce this?

@david-allison And I'd like to know exactly what you mean by `preferences overview`. Is that the preferences first pages with the top headers (General, Sync, Reviewing, etc)? Because it's what I initially think when I see "overview".', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 18, 22, 57, 10, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 923950817, 'comment_body': "I don't have a corrupted collection but if you want to make a test you could check for 'illFatedDb' in the tests directory and see how we corrupt one programmatically - combining the existing test collections we have as fixtures and the same idea of opening the file and scribbling in it (that is: overwriting a chunk with :hankey: data) might be useful? That test was easier for me to write then I thought when I tried it so I'm not trying to suggest something really painful, it might be easy to do", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 19, 0, 2, 26, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'mikehardy', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 924035235, 'comment_body': 'Sure, bring it it and mark with `Keep Open`', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 19, 3, 55, 17, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'david-allison', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 925027037, 'comment_body': "After spending weeks thinking about it, I've finally designed a reliable process to create a corrupted collection. Beware that it may me too complex.

Step 1: rename any file to `collection.anki2`
Step 2: replace the old collection with it
Step 3: there isn't a step 3

This is the default patterns we can follow with a corrupt collection:
https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/179859192-daa6f198-bdcd-4355-8578-de3b0fb9658c.mp4

So we can't go to the preferences with a corrupt collection.

But you are still right that there is a way to go to the advanced screen on a startup error (at least theoratically)

https://github.com/ankidroid/Anki-Android/blob/31cfbc914a7467eaeeeb74a461821f1166d707f5/AnkiDroid/src/main/java/com/ichi2/anki/DeckPicker.kt#L478-L483

And DIRECTORY_NOT_ACCESSIBLE is thrown here

https://github.com/ankidroid/Anki-Android/blob/1373897c73a613d745958ad0fdbc9d32cfdae4a8/AnkiDroid/src/main/java/com/ichi2/anki/InitialActivity.kt#L45-L46

Which will depends on isCurrentAnkiDroidDirAccessible returning false

https://github.com/ankidroid/Anki-Android/blob/5a586f622a06507e9a8aeae92c49b8058fd76cc9/AnkiDroid/src/main/java/com/ichi2/anki/CollectionHelper.java#L327-L335

Which is only the case if initializeAnkiDirectory fails

https://github.com/ankidroid/Anki-Android/blob/5a586f622a06507e9a8aeae92c49b8058fd76cc9/AnkiDroid/src/main/java/com/ichi2/anki/CollectionHelper.java#L302-L320

On my tests, if write permission hasn't been granted, it doesn't lead to the advanced screen, so discard that option

So the only other way is to fail `dir.mkdirs` and I don't know how to fail it on a real use scenario, so I need help here to conclude if it's possible or not to get to the advanced screen with a unnacessible directory.

If it's not possible, there isn't a issue to solve here. If it is possible, I think that opening Android's directory picker is a better UX than opening the advanced screen.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 19, 23, 7, 37, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 925029398, 'comment_body': "Kindly related, I've discovered another issue while researching this:

DatabaseErrorDialog shouldn't be cancellable by outside touches. 

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/179863188-2bd71437-4189-468f-a0f5-8159e24cace9.mp4

It leads to crashes if I open the Card Browser, Statistics and a lot of other things.

Task here is to add `cancelOnTouchOutside(false)` to `DatabaseErrorDialog`", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 19, 23, 12, 5, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 925032625, 'comment_body': "Shouldn't this have solved the TODO? https://github.com/ankidroid/Anki-Android/pull/9213", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 19, 23, 18, 20, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 925348203, 'comment_body': 'Totally right, sorry for the misdirection', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 20, 8, 51, 41, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'david-allison', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 927119563, 'comment_body': "Okay, now that I look better at it, I actually haven't added a `col!!` call on `AdvancedSettingsFragment` + it isn't possible to navigate back to the preferences main screen as the fragment is called with `getSubscreenIntent`, so I really can't see the issue here. 

There was another `col!!` call on `AdvancedSettingsFragment`, but I've fixed it on the last commit just in case", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 21, 21, 32, 12, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 928251268, 'comment_body': "Why?
It's not blocking, but since it was already being redone, I would have thought it could be done at the same time", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 24, 12, 36, 20, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 928256924, 'comment_body': "This means that the previous commits may lead to a crash, and we know it. 
As a matter of principle, I would have preferred this commit to arrive sooner to avoid it.
In practice, since it does not break tests, it won't impact bisect, and it's not like we'll sheep intermediary version, so no practical reason to block here.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 24, 13, 17, 56, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 928257598, 'comment_body': '#11874 is built on top of this and I would like to avoid the chance of getting conflicts and having to spend time fixing them.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 24, 13, 23, 20, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}]

pr_title: [GSoC] Refactor preferences update
pr_body:
Continuation of #11873

## Purpose / Description

Updating preferences was problematic, with [updatePreference](https://github.com/ankidroid/Anki-Android/blob/abd1f8bfc316cdf11aba51af7bda7f5b05c493d7/AnkiDroid/src/main/java/com/ichi2/anki/Preferences.kt#L438) being ran every time any preference is changed. Also, the preferences activity had the responsability of mananing methods of specific preferences, which isn't a good design (e.g. [this](https://github.com/ankidroid/Anki-Android/blob/abd1f8bfc316cdf11aba51af7bda7f5b05c493d7/AnkiDroid/src/main/java/com/ichi2/anki/Preferences.kt#L280))

To keep things tidy, concise, and keep the preferences' configuration responsability on themselves and on their screens, I've done some refactors on the preferences activity

## Approach

1. Extract the preferences update to their screens on the `Update X preference individually` commits
- The required changes that escape the previous patternare marked on the commits as a `**` on the message beginning and are described on their respective commit messages.

## How Has This Been Tested?

Manually opened/changed all preferences and it still works correctly. I should upload a video of it later.

## Checklist
_Please, go through these checks before submitting the PR._

- [X] You have not changed whitespace unnecessarily (it makes diffs hard to read)
- [X] You have a descriptive commit message with a short title (first line, max 50 chars).
- [X] Your code follows the style of the project (e.g. never omit braces in `if` statements) 
- [X] You have commented your code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas
- [X] You have performed a self-review of your own code
- [ ] UI changes: include screenshots of all affected screens (in particular showing any new or changed strings)
- [ ] UI Changes: You have tested your change using the [Google Accessibility Scanner](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.google.android.apps.accessibility.auditor)

pr_body:

Very straightforward

1. Create a new file with the fragment name

4. Commit and go back to the first step

pr_title: [GSoC] NF: Add a comment explaining setTargetFragment deprecation suppression
pr_body:
## Purpose / Description
As I've commented on #9452:

Currently, the only place setTargetFragment is used is on Preferences.kt

It is necessary to use it, because AndroidX PreferenceDialogFragmentCompat calls getTargetFragment(). If this happens without setTargetFragment getting called before, it leads to a crash, which means that we can't exchange it to [setFragmentResultListener](https://developer.android.com/reference/androidx/fragment/app/FragmentManager#setFragmentResultListener(java.lang.String,androidx.lifecycle.LifecycleOwner,androidx.fragment.app.FragmentResultListener)) as well.

This is definitely a upstream problem, and the current best course of action is to suppress the warning and give a +1 to these issues on Google issue tracker:

https://issuetracker.google.com/issues/181793702
https://issuetracker.google.com/issues/212905758

## Checklist
_Please, go through these checks before submitting the PR._

- [X] You have not changed whitespace unnecessarily (it makes diffs hard to read)
- [X] You have a descriptive commit message with a short title (first line, max 50 chars).
- [X] Your code follows the style of the project (e.g. never omit braces in `if` statements) 
- [X] You have commented your code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas
- [X] You have performed a self-review of your own code
- [ ] UI changes: include screenshots of all affected screens (in particular showing any new or changed strings)
- [ ] UI Changes: You have tested your change using the [Google Accessibility Scanner](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.google.android.apps.accessibility.auditor)

pr_title: [GSoC] Reorganize some preferences + refactors
pr_body:
## Purpose / Description
~~On top of #11919~~

This is the last preferences reorganization PR I want to do for GSoC. Previously I'd thought about moving all the preferences from Advanced to the other screens, but after thinking a while, I've come to the conclusion that the it's best to keep it as a bucket of "Things most users won't need or are really advanced, therefore they shouldn't dispute space with the relevant ones".

As an example we have `Simple typed answer formatting`, only useful if typed answer is used AND the typed answer uses Polytonic Greek characters AND older webviews are being used (see #7901 if you are curious).

Other preferences there will be gone some day (e.g. `Replace newlines with HTML` when the visual editor is implemented). Others can be moved to the activities they impact (e.g. `Default deck when opening statistics` being moved to the statistics screen). And others need analytics (#11642) to evaluate if they can be discarded.

So, overall there isn't anything else I want to move right now.


## Approach
- Moved preferences:
    - `HTML/Javascript debug`: Advanced ‚Üí Developer options
    - `Card browser` and `Anki card` context menus, and `Press back twite to go back/exit`: Advanced ‚Üí General
    - `Card browser font scaling`: Appearance ‚Üí Accessibility
- Removed `V2 scheduler` preference
    - 142f789a7bddaf46fbc4f9bd7e32defd3e4ae84d forces/requires/prompts to use the V2 scheduler when the user tries to study, so this preference is no longer necessary
- Build summaries for the remaining categories (General, Appearance and Advanced)
- Some cleanups around HeaderFragment.kt

## How Has This Been Tested?

Opened the app and opened the preferences categories to see if I get any crash

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/181976491-8194e168-c999-48b6-a33e-c46ec44dd99e.mp4

## Checklist
_Please, go through these checks before submitting the PR._

- [X] You have not changed whitespace unnecessarily (it makes diffs hard to read)
- [X] You have a descriptive commit message with a short title (first line, max 50 chars).
- [X] Your code follows the style of the project (e.g. never omit braces in `if` statements) 
- [X] You have commented your code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas
- [X] You have performed a self-review of your own code
- [X] UI changes: include screenshots of all affected screens (in particular showing any new or changed strings)
- [ ] UI Changes: You have tested your change using the [Google Accessibility Scanner](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.google.android.apps.accessibility.auditor)

', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 31, 6, 27, 36, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'krmanik', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 933961901, 'comment_body': "The strings can be removed on the future if they aren't really necessary, so I'll keep them for now to avoid blocking the PR.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 31, 10, 12, 50, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 933989556, 'comment_body': 'This feature is intended for non debug builds, for end users. - The V16 pref is useful to testing in case the dev forgot to set `legacy_schema=false` on `local.properties` while not having to re-enable every time the app is reopened.

## Fixes
A tiny bit of #6772

## Approach
On the commits

Emulator SDK 25

pr_title: [GSoC] refactor: Migrate preferences formatted summaries configuration to the XMLs
pr_body:
## Purpose / Description
It's better to keep the UI configuration as much as possible on the XMLs, so this is a step toward this goal.

## Approach
On the commits

## How Has This Been Tested?

Ran the app and saw if everything was the same way as before

## Learning (optional, can help others)
For some unknown reason (I've discovered by chance), getAttributeResourceValue only works for the custom namespace if "http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto" is set as namespace too.

Actually we should declare attributes on `attrs.xml` and get rid of the custom namespace everywhere. But I'm not doing this today (nor in the near future, as this envolves fixing DeckOptions and FilteredDeckOptions's prefs too)

## Checklist

pr_title: [GSoC] refactor preferences style attributes
pr_body:
## Purpose / Description
Use style attributes the way Android intends to and simplify some preferences' constructors to improve Android Studio's layout previews

## Approach
On the commits

## How Has This Been Tested?

1. See if the summaries are looking right on Android Studio's layout previewer now that this is possible
2. Run the app and do the same thing on it 

## Learning (optional, can help others)

pr_title: [GSoC] Add a lint rule to use string resources for preferences keys + extract deck options/filtered deck options keys
pr_body:
## Fixes
Fixes #10423

## Approach
For the key extractions, just used a regex to replace the strings for keys, searching for `android:(?:key|dependency)="([^@].*?)"`. Deck options keys were replaced by `deck_options_KEYNAME_key` and filtered deck options were replaced by `filtered_deck_KEYNAME_key`. This way the change was easy to do and probably will be easy to review.

## How Has This Been Tested?

Ran lint and the unit tests created

## Checklist
_Please, go through these checks before submitting the PR._

- [X] You have not changed whitespace unnecessarily (it makes diffs hard to read)

pr_title: [GSoC] Add option to import text files
pr_body:
## Purpose / Description
This just adds the option, not the actual text/csv import implementation. which will be the next PR

As the CSV importer will require the new backend, the options is only shown if the new backend is enabled

## Approach
On the commits

## How Has This Been Tested?

1. Enable the new backend
2. Tap the three dot menu on the Deck picker > Import
3. Choose "Text file (.txt, .csv)
4. Select a text file
5. See if the "CSV importer is not implemented yet" is shown

pr_title: [GSoC] Implement the CSV importer
pr_body:
## Purpose / Description
On top of #12072

## Fixes
Closes #6772
Closes #9437

## Approach

This implements the base for using upstream's HTML/Js pages directly on AnkiDroid.

I've used https://github.com/krmanik/Anki-Android/pull/23 as base of this PR. I wouldn't have managed to do it without all the previous work of Mani and Damien, so I thank them very much.

As discussed on https://github.com/krmanik/Anki-Android/pull/23, to use an Anki HTML page, we should be able to intercept POST requests. After some proof of concepts made by Mani, the conclusion was that hosting a local server, like the desktop application, may be most suitable approach.

To create the local server, I've used the same approach of https://github.com/krmanik/Anki-Android/pull/23 and added NanoHTTPD, a java server library, as dependency. I don't have experience with any Java server libraries, so I can't tell with confidence if this is *the best library*, but it seemed solid to me and already had a working model on Mani's PR, so using it looked like the best choice for the moment.

Besides the server, this PR implements the base classes for creating AnkiPages. Each page can easily extend `PageFragment` and define what it needs. I've tried using the new Statistics, Card Info, Deck Options pages and they work well. Try https://github.com/BrayanDSO/Anki-Android/tree/csvImporterOtherPages if you want to test them (the deck options screen may need some extra work).

Finally, the CSV importer page and its endpoints are implemented and can be used with the new backend.

**PENDING (for future PRs):**
- Close the Import dialog after the taps "OK" on the progress dialog
- Inject CSS to match the themes' colors
- ~~Maybe hide the file path with CSS/Js, because it may be big and there isn't much horizontal space in phone screens on portrait mode~~ (already on upstream)
- Not for my GSoC project, but the other screens could be implemented too, as they are mostly done, so other people could test/work on them as well

## How Has This Been Tested?

NOTICE: this needs an updated WebView (77+) to work correctly (see https://github.com/ankidroid/Anki-Android/issues/6772#issuecomment-1209212058 and the comments below for discussion), which shouldn't be a problem as the project's minSdk (21) supports it. But if you are testing on a emulator, be aware that the WebView shipped on some older SDK versions may be an old version, so either update the WebView or use a newer SDK.

NOTICE 2: there may be a flickering issue after remapping fields, but that was already solved on upstream (https://github.com/ankitects/anki/pull/2005)

1. Enable the new backend (Settings > Advanced)
2. Deck picker > Three dot menu > Import > Text file
3. Select a CSV file (I've tested with Anking, pretty heavy and popular deck)
    - Here's a mini version (23KB) if anyone wants to test it: [MiniAnking.txt](https://github.com/ankidroid/Anki-Android/files/9383917/MiniAnking.txt)
    - And here's a slightly cut version (GitHub only allows files up to 25MB): 
[Anking.txt](https://github.com/ankidroid/Anki-Android/files/9383942/Anking.txt)
4. Configure anything on the CSV importer
5. Tap Import


https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/185787227-5df94718-f6d4-472a-8301-159f4628110d.mp4



## Checklist
_Please, go through these checks before submitting the PR._

- [X] You have not changed whitespace unnecessarily (it makes diffs hard to read)
- [X] You have a descriptive commit message with a short title (first line, max 50 chars).
- [X] Your code follows the style of the project (e.g. never omit braces in `if` statements) 
- [X] You have commented your code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas
- [X] You have performed a self-review of your own code
- [X] UI changes: include screenshots of all affected screens (in particular showing any new or changed strings)
- [ ] UI Changes: You have tested your change using the [Google Accessibility Scanner](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.google.android.apps.accessibility.auditor)

pr_title: [GSoC] Add preference to allow/warn if using metered connections
pr_body:
## Pull Request template

## Purpose / Description
Internet may be expensive üíµüí∞üí≤üí∏

## Fixes
Fixes #10706

## Approach
- Clean things a bit
- Create a "Advanced" category under "Sync", so things get a little more organized with the increasing number of preferences
- Add a preference to allow sync on metered connections (off by default)
     - If not allowed, auto sync under metered connections won't occur + the user will be warned if they trigger a manual sync under a metered connection
     - I'm quite open to string changes

## How Has This Been Tested?

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/185769043-30b76c32-5e89-4b27-93b2-156638e26204.mp4


## Checklist
_Please, go through these checks before submitting the PR._

- [X] You have a descriptive commit message with a short title (first line, max 50 chars).
- [X] You have commented your code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas
- [X] You have performed a self-review of your own code
- [X] UI changes: include screenshots of all affected screens (in particular showing any new or changed strings)
- [ ] UI Changes: You have tested your change using the [Google Accessibility Scanner](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.google.android.apps.accessibility.auditor)

The changes look good and I'm not fixed on the string change so I'm leaving this dialog string issue to the second reviewer. ', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 12, 12, 15, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lukstbit', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950905250, 'comment_body': 'Implementor choice:

You're not keeping any state, and you don't have to access it from java.
So you can probably remove it", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 22, 6, 20, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950906164, 'comment_body': 'You can remove `: Boolean {` and replace with `=`', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 22, 6, 43, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950906321, 'comment_body': "Implementor choice: I'd personally use `run` or `let` and put the `as` inside the block.
", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 22, 8, 24, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950907538, 'comment_body': 'I am very much against it.
I prefer that we use an enum with three values, yes, no, unknown. 

I'll admit that in any case, we will never get real valid information, and that's a shame. So we should never be assertive one way or another. 
This is requiring the user to grasp a concept that is not necessarily straighforward. I prefer that we are able to tell them honestly when we can't know instead of mixing it with the case where we are sure.
I agree it makes sense to behave in the same way in both case, and ask for confirmation. However, I hope we can have different warning messages

I'm not sure for JS how to transform it. I'd consider using two boolean function, except that I would not want that each card do the request twice. Is there an easy way to send an enum to JS? Otherwise, I'd want the function to be
`isConnectionNotMetered` with `0` meaning false, `1` true, and `2` "unknown". So that if a code just do `if(!isConnectionNotMetered) {useNetwork}` it uses network only if it is certain it's okay to do so.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 22, 21, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950907972, 'comment_body': "Can you please document which exception you expect. 
I suspect that `getInstance` and `applicationContext` can't really fail. At least, not in a way that matter to us. If we can't get applicationContext, we probably want to actually fail here. So maybe just put the try/catch around the part whose failure will really be related to connectivity.
", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 22, 25, 46, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950908248, 'comment_body': "Seems long to me. I'd suggest a new line after each .
Generally, i'd consider that it's nice to have either everything on a single line or one call by line.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 22, 27, 50, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950909341, 'comment_body': 'Most of it together would do

```Kotlin
enum class Metered {
    YES(),
    NO(),
    UNKNOWN();
}
fun meteredFromBool(b: Boolean) = if (b) Metered.YES else Metered.NO;

fun isActiveNetworkMetered(): Metered {
    val context = AnkiDroidApp
        .getInstance()
        .applicationContext
    val cm = try {
        context.getSystemService(Context.CONNECTIVITY_SERVICE) as ConnectivityManager
    } catch (e: Exception) {
        Timber.w(e, "Exception obtaining metered connection")
        return Metered.UNKNOWN
    }
    return meteredFromBool(cm.isActiveNetworkMetered)
}
```

I cancelled some suggestion above because adding enum and smal try/catch means that some advice makes no sense globally', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 22, 38, 58, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950912147, 'comment_body': "I'd appreciate a little javadoc on it.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 23, 5, 58, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950912445, 'comment_body': "I'd appreciate for a next time that you do this in multiple commit.

AnkiDroid's manifest has it, so I don't think that the try catch is necessary.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 22, 0, 7, 25, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950923435, 'comment_body': "`doSync` is mostly only useful inside `sync()`, so to reduce boilerplate, I've kept it as a nested function. The latest changes look ok.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 12, 55, 1, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lukstbit', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 954011992, 'comment_body': 'I think I'll keep it with the current way.

Or use a button that leads directly to the settings screen and highlight the preference. Or anything else', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 16, 20, 50, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 954031917, 'comment_body': 'Why rename `syncMedia`?', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 16, 39, 40, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'oakkitten', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 954060354, 'comment_body': "There wasn't a syncMedia when I first did the PR. Probably got it after the rebase. It doesn't seem relevant, so I'll spare myself the time of changing it back", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 17, 8, 40, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 954171164, 'comment_body': 'I'm ambivalent on the name as long as it all still works but @oakkitten was just *all* over this code making it work well for custom sync servers, so making sure it works after all the custom sync server work is important. From that perspective it may not be resolved in their mind, and that's legitimate from perspective of "time spent wrestling with this mess"', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 18, 45, 24, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'mikehardy', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 954180905, 'comment_body': "I am one of those people who spend ‚Öî of their coding time naming and renaming things üôà

Anyway, `syncFetchesMedia` implies that only fetching is happening and not uploading, which is confusing. I suppose at some point this setting did something else. So I went with `syncMedia`, which is also the name of the called function parameter.

Oh well it's not really important.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 18, 53, 29, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'oakkitten', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 954197145, 'comment_body': 'now definitely resolved :laughing: - last commit moves it', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 19, 8, 24, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'mikehardy', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 954362786, 'comment_body': "@Arthur-Milchior in your review you wanted an enum, with this refactor here to a simple util method, I think this is clean and correct and just binary. The assertion it is correct is that from the perspective of consuming people's money (using metered data) defaulting to a cautious stance of assuming it is metered when we catch an (almost entirely impossible) exception is the right one.

So I think this may answer your review comments well", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 22, 55, 13, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'mikehardy', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 955980589, 'comment_body': "Sorry, I didn't realize on first read that you were extracting a method. I still believes my remarks make sense, but it can wait then. ", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 26, 12, 13, 44, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 955997553, 'comment_body': 'I'm fine with the commint "Add preference to check if sync is on metered connection" except for his title

Also, you are not adding adding a preference but taking it into account. I suggest it may be nice to indicates both fact', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 26, 12, 35, 36, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 956014860, 'comment_body': 'As far as I can tell, this commit does not change the slightest the actual code used. If most people agree that as soon as we get an exception, we warn in the same way, fine by me I guess. 
Anyway, this PR is already a great improvement, and if I can convince peolpe, the change can be done later easily.

One regret I have, but that always can be dealt with later too is that we should send a crash report. I'd love to know if it's something that actually occurs, hether it's related to specific version of the API or specific manufacturers. Also maybe what exceptions we actually get. So that maybe later we could get a better catching and warning



 (By the way, this did not seems to require an extra commit. You could just have directly create the file without any enclosing "object NetworkUtils" when you created the file

', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 26, 12, 56, 23, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 956035976, 'comment_body': 'Nit: we may avoid all variables and directly use an experssion

        .getInstance()
        .applicationContext
        .getSystemService(Context.CONNECTIVITY_SERVICE)
        .let {it as ConnectivityManager}

pr_title: [GSoC] NF: Remove the old CSV importer implementation

pr_title: [GSoC] Make the CSV importer accept .csv and .tsv extensions
pr_body:
## Approach
to do it, an "extraMimes" param is added to openImportFilePicker, which can be passed to the intent wish a "EXTRA_MIME_TYPES" as extra.

ref: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27367272/how-can-i-setup-an-android-intent-for-multiple-types-of-files-pdf-office-imag

## How Has This Been Tested?

- Enable the new backend
- Import > Text file
- See if you can select .csv, .tsv and .txt

pr_title: [GSoC] Optimize preferences search bar configuration + enable search history
pr_body:
## Pull Request template

## Purpose / Description
On the 2.3.0 version of SearchPreference, the visibility of SearchConfiguration is now protected instead of private.

This allows saving and setting the search bar configuration instead of recreating it every time the menu is recreated, which happens when any fragment is opened

And about the search history: It was disabled before because the saved entries weren't good (see https://github.com/ByteHamster/SearchPreference/issues/25)

## Approach
On the commits

## How Has This Been Tested?

Settings > Tap the search icon > search something and tap an option > tap the search icon again > see the history

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/188272464-2e738897-8c98-4434-92d5-4a671b115466.png)

pr_title: Make non fuzzy searches case insensitive by default
pr_body:
Hi there. A problem I had with the library was that the searches were case sensitive with `fuzzySearch` disabled. This way, it was harder to make any search.

Here I add a case sensitivity option. 

I'm happy to do any changes with the approach if necessary.
pr_review_comments:
[{'comment_id': 916074577, 'comment_body': "There is a classic issue here - that for instance Turkish capital I does not map to the lower-i you expect, so this is a common lint failure - not specifying a Locale. If you don't really care about the Locale though and just want it to be predictable / not rely on user device setting you use Root

This suggestion may require addition of an import of the Locale symbol above



```suggestion
            return getInfo().toLowerCase(Locale.ROOT).contains(keyword.toLowerCase());
```

@ByteHamster :wave: hi by the way, we are here from https://github.com/ankidroid/Anki-Android and thinking of integrating this library in our app :-) ", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 7, 16, 34, 6, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'mikehardy', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 916161959, 'comment_body': 'Oh, really interesting. Thanks, Mike. Fixed it', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 7, 18, 20, 57, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 916200079, 'comment_body': "@mikehardy, on a second thought, actually isn't it better to use `Locale.getDefault()`, which should match the app's language?", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 7, 19, 8, 39, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 916360839, 'comment_body': '@BrayanDSO that's a good point, I think mentally I was stuck on the "stock" normal issue where it is lower-casing fixed strings but in this case they should be translated, so the user's default would be best. However, remember in AnkiDroid that the language can be user selected and *not* the system locale. Tricky one. :thinking: - do we have a Context anywhere we may pull Locale from ? The one may actually require some testing or something to "feel" it and make sure it really works as expected. 

For whatever it is worth, here's the typical issue: https://garygregory.wordpress.com/2015/11/03/java-lowercase-conversion-turkey/ / https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23524231/lower-case-of-turkish-character-dotted-i

Apparently it may be as easy as going toUpperCase instead of lower which has the potential to be a  brilliant "work smarter not harder" solution. I've only ever seen it bite personally on Turkish I when going toLower so maybe it's just that easy.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 8, 0, 2, 11, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'mikehardy', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 916363636, 'comment_body': '> However, remember in AnkiDroid that the language can be user selected and not the system locale.

`Locale.getDefault()` returns the app language, not system's. I know because of the work on `buildCategorySummary`'s RTL support (https://github.com/ankidroid/Anki-Android/commit/f9e886fe8ca6eb0f57927c8255205faf9ab704e0#diff-47297e4165b250a242c0ed3e241814b88ca539c48a7f01dedce81a34ee15f3a3R46-R49).

As preferences strings follow the app's strings/locale as well, `Locale.getDefault()` makes sense. It should work accordingly with the current approach. 

> Apparently it may be as easy as going toUpperCase instead of lower which has the potential to be a brilliant "work smarter not harder" solution. I've only ever seen it bite personally on Turkish I when going toLower so maybe it's just that easy.

üíØ, will change it.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 8, 0, 10, 32, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 916367381, 'comment_body': "> Also, a Turkish can say that ‚ÄúKedi‚Äù.toUpperCase() works on Turkey but won‚Äôt work in the rest of the world (Kedi is Cat in Turkish). ‚ÄúKedi‚Äù.toUpperCase() using an en_ES Locale will return KEDI while with Turkish Locale will return KEDƒ∞. It all depends on the perspective

Hmmmm. As per this comment in one of the links you addressed (https://garygregory.wordpress.com/2015/11/03/java-lowercase-conversion-turkey/), vice-versa is valid as well. So uppercasing X lowercasing methods doesn't makes a difference. But as long as locale is kept, it should work. 

Although it shouldn't matter,  I'll go with lowercasing as most text is lowercase", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 8, 0, 22, 30, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 916411373, 'comment_body': '"And today I learned..." - but joking tone aside, this is a difficult issue! So I'm glad to learn more, thanks for posting that. Agreed using default locale (assuming that's what "you can pick your language apps" are affecting) seems valid. ', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 8, 2, 23, 25, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'mikehardy', 'type': 'User'}]

pr_title: Make possible to index and ignore preferences programatically
pr_body:
Hi there! Here's the PR I said I would do.

This aims to solve two problems of mine:
- Index preferences programatically: as some are built programatically on AnkiDroid instead of on the XMLs
- Ignore preferences programatically: as some can't be used by everyone, e.g. newer API features and device specific settings (e.g. E-ink)

Please feel free to push back about the implementation.

I think I won't need any more changes to the library, so you can release a new version after this is merged. Pinging @ByteHamster just in case you haven't got the notification. Sorry to bother.

pr_title: Make easier to extend SearchPreferenceActionView
pr_body: Hi, sorry to bother again. This PR proposes a few ergonomic changes to make easier to extend SearchPreferenceActionView. I know I could override them with some reflection, but I've thought that proposing a PR here may help anyone else trying to do the same thing.

pr_body:

pr_title: [GSoC] Add preference to allow/warn if using metered connections
pr_body:
## Pull Request template

## Purpose / Description
Internet may be expensive üíµüí∞üí≤üí∏

## Fixes
Fixes #10706

## Approach
- Clean things a bit
- Create a "Advanced" category under "Sync", so things get a little more organized with the increasing number of preferences
- Add a preference to allow sync on metered connections (off by default)
     - If not allowed, auto sync under metered connections won't occur + the user will be warned if they trigger a manual sync under a metered connection
     - I'm quite open to string changes

## How Has This Been Tested?

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/185769043-30b76c32-5e89-4b27-93b2-156638e26204.mp4


## Checklist
_Please, go through these checks before submitting the PR._

- [X] You have a descriptive commit message with a short title (first line, max 50 chars).
- [X] You have commented your code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas
- [X] You have performed a self-review of your own code
- [X] UI changes: include screenshots of all affected screens (in particular showing any new or changed strings)
- [ ] UI Changes: You have tested your change using the [Google Accessibility Scanner](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.google.android.apps.accessibility.auditor)
pr_review_comments:
[{'comment_id': 950825453, 'comment_body': "Aren't we supposed to use the string preferences constants that you've been working on?", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 10, 52, 36, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lukstbit', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950825670, 'comment_body': 'I propose:

_Your connection is metered so this data transfer may cost money. If you are ok with syncing on metered connections you can disable this dialog in Settings-Sync._  

or something else that informs the user about the relevant setting in the app settings.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 10, 55, 4, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lukstbit', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950827912, 'comment_body': 'Maybe adding a checkbox "Don't warn next time" on the dialog would be good? (Is this possible/easy to do on Material dialog?)', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 11, 11, 43, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950835854, 'comment_body': 'I would actually prefer the string change because it mentions the setting.
One issue using the checkbox  would be if the user checks "don't warn me" and then selects cancel. At this point the sync would silently fail and could confuse the user(also the material dialogs library allows for a checkbox).

The changes look good and I'm not fixed on the string change so I'm leaving this dialog string issue to the second reviewer. ', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 12, 12, 15, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lukstbit', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950905250, 'comment_body': 'Implementor choice:
`fun ankiIsActiveNetworkMetered() = NetworkUtils.isActiveNetworkMetered()`', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 21, 57, 6, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950906129, 'comment_body': "Unless I got it wrong, `object` is useless. You're not keeping any state, and you don't have to access it from java.
So you can probably remove it", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 22, 6, 20, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950906164, 'comment_body': 'You can remove `: Boolean {` and replace with `=`', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 22, 6, 43, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950906321, 'comment_body': "Implementor choice: I'd personally use `run` or `let` and put the `as` inside the block.
", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 22, 8, 24, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950907538, 'comment_body': 'I am very much against it.
I prefer that we use an enum with three values, yes, no, unknown. 

I'll admit that in any case, we will never get real valid information, and that's a shame. So we should never be assertive one way or another. 
This is requiring the user to grasp a concept that is not necessarily straighforward. I prefer that we are able to tell them honestly when we can't know instead of mixing it with the case where we are sure.
I agree it makes sense to behave in the same way in both case, and ask for confirmation. However, I hope we can have different warning messages

I'm not sure for JS how to transform it. I'd consider using two boolean function, except that I would not want that each card do the request twice. Is there an easy way to send an enum to JS? Otherwise, I'd want the function to be
`isConnectionNotMetered` with `0` meaning false, `1` true, and `2` "unknown". So that if a code just do `if(!isConnectionNotMetered) {useNetwork}` it uses network only if it is certain it's okay to do so.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 22, 21, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950907972, 'comment_body': "Can you please document which exception you expect. 
I suspect that `getInstance` and `applicationContext` can't really fail. At least, not in a way that matter to us. If we can't get applicationContext, we probably want to actually fail here. So maybe just put the try/catch around the part whose failure will really be related to connectivity.
", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 22, 25, 46, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950908248, 'comment_body': "Seems long to me. I'd suggest a new line after each .
Generally, i'd consider that it's nice to have either everything on a single line or one call by line.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 22, 27, 50, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950909341, 'comment_body': 'Most of it together would do

```Kotlin
enum class Metered {
    YES(),
    NO(),
    UNKNOWN();
}
fun meteredFromBool(b: Boolean) = if (b) Metered.YES else Metered.NO;

fun isActiveNetworkMetered(): Metered {
    val context = AnkiDroidApp
        .getInstance()
        .applicationContext
    val cm = try {
        context.getSystemService(Context.CONNECTIVITY_SERVICE) as ConnectivityManager
    } catch (e: Exception) {
        Timber.w(e, "Exception obtaining metered connection")
        return Metered.UNKNOWN
    }
    return meteredFromBool(cm.isActiveNetworkMetered)
}
```

I cancelled some suggestion above because adding enum and smal try/catch means that some advice makes no sense globally', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 22, 38, 58, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950912147, 'comment_body': "I'd appreciate a little javadoc on it.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 23, 5, 58, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950912445, 'comment_body': "I'd appreciate for a next time that you do this in multiple commit. 
* Extracting variables in a commit, 
* extracting doSync
* then taking into account whether it's metered

We can put it in a separate PR and squash it, but it would really help to review and save me time", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 21, 23, 8, 40, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950922479, 'comment_body': "I particularly prefer functions stating `return`, so I'll keep that", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 22, 0, 4, 30, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950922914, 'comment_body': "I actually just copied and pasted the method, a 100% straight extraction. It wasn't my goal to refactor it on this PR.

But I agree if your points. Looking on the source code, I only expect it to return an error in the case there isn't a specific permission on the manifest. AnkiDroid's manifest has it, so I don't think that the try catch is necessary.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 22, 0, 7, 25, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950923435, 'comment_body': "`doSync` is mostly only useful inside `sync()`, so to reduce boilerplate, I've kept it as a nested function. Added a javadoc to make it more clear. Let me know if that is fine", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 22, 0, 10, 52, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 950923778, 'comment_body': "After I changed isActiveNetworkMetered, creating a enum may not be necessary anymore, as I've removed the try-catch ", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 22, 0, 12, 59, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 953765458, 'comment_body': '@BrayanDSO Have you decided on this? The latest changes look ok.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 12, 55, 1, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lukstbit', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 954011992, 'comment_body': 'I think I'll keep it with the current way. 

In the future someone else can create a new string and concatenate with this one. Or use a "Don't warn me" checkbox. Or use a button that leads directly to the settings screen and highlight the preference. Or anything else', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 16, 20, 50, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 954031917, 'comment_body': 'Why rename `syncMedia`?', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 16, 39, 40, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'oakkitten', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 954060354, 'comment_body': "There wasn't a syncMedia when I first did the PR. Probably got it after the rebase. It doesn't seem relevant, so I'll spare myself the time of changing it back", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 17, 8, 40, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 954171164, 'comment_body': 'I'm ambivalent on the name as long as it all still works but @oakkitten was just *all* over this code making it work well for custom sync servers, so making sure it works after all the custom sync server work is important. From that perspective it may not be resolved in their mind, and that's legitimate from perspective of "time spent wrestling with this mess"', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 18, 45, 24, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'mikehardy', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 954180905, 'comment_body': "I am one of those people who spend ‚Öî of their coding time naming and renaming things üôà

Anyway, `syncFetchesMedia` implies that only fetching is happening and not uploading, which is confusing. I suppose at some point this setting did something else. So I went with `syncMedia`, which is also the name of the called function parameter.

Oh well it's not really important.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 18, 53, 29, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'oakkitten', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 954197145, 'comment_body': 'now definitely resolved :laughing: - last commit moves it', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 19, 8, 24, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'mikehardy', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 954362786, 'comment_body': "@Arthur-Milchior in your review you wanted an enum, with this refactor here to a simple util method, I think this is clean and correct and just binary. The assertion it is correct is that from the perspective of consuming people's money (using metered data) defaulting to a cautious stance of assuming it is metered when we catch an (almost entirely impossible) exception is the right one.

So I think this may answer your review comments well", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 22, 55, 13, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'mikehardy', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 955980589, 'comment_body': "Sorry, I didn't realize on first read that you were extracting a method. Then I guess fine.

I still believes my remarks make sense, but it can wait then. ", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 26, 12, 13, 44, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 955997553, 'comment_body': 'I'm fine with the commint "Add preference to check if sync is on metered connection" except for his title
You're adding a permission request, that should be in the commit message.
Also, you are not adding adding a preference but taking it into account. I suggest it may be nice to indicates both fact', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 26, 12, 35, 36, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 956014860, 'comment_body': 'As far as I can tell, this commit does not change the slightest the actual code used. It just ensures that we remove the `object` from the file.

If most people agree that as soon as we get an exception, we warn in the same way, fine by me I guess. 
Anyway, this PR is already a great improvement, and if I can convince peolpe, the change can be done later easily.

One regret I have, but that always can be dealt with later too is that we should send a crash report. I'd love to know if it's something that actually occurs, hether it's related to specific version of the API or specific manufacturers. Also maybe what exceptions we actually get. So that maybe later we could get a better catching and warning



 (By the way, this did not seems to require an extra commit. You could just have directly create the file without any enclosing "object NetworkUtils" when you created the file

', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 26, 12, 56, 23, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 956035976, 'comment_body': 'Nit: we may avoid all variables and directly use an experssion

```kotlin
fun isActiveNetworkMetered() = 
    AnkiDroidApp
        .getInstance()
        .applicationContext
        .getSystemService(Context.CONNECTIVITY_SERVICE)
        .let {it as ConnectivityManager}
        .isActiveNetworkMetered
```', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 26, 13, 20, 3, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 956042909, 'comment_body': "I'd consider adding it in the commit you created the method. ", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 26, 13, 27, 18, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'Arthur-Milchior', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 956157296, 'comment_body': 'Thanks for the heads up. Changed the commit message to:

> Add "Allow sync on metered connections" preference
If disabled, auto-sync isn't triggered on metered connections and the user is asked if they want to continue if they trigger a manual sync
If enabled, sync occurs normally', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 26, 15, 22, 17, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'BrayanDSO', 'type': 'User'}]

pr_title: [GSoC] Reorganize reviewing preferences
pr_body:
## Approach
1. Move `New time zone handling` and `Double tap time` to a subcategory called `Advanced`
2. Rename `behavior` subcategory to `scheduling`
3. Remove Whiteboard stroke width preference
4. Create a new subcategory called `Accessibility` on Appearance and move some of the reviewing preferences there
5. Create a new subcategory called `Reviewer` on Appearance and move some of the reviewing preferences there
6. Build Reviewing category from other strings


https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/174076398-4c62ad02-a4a0-4dc7-bcbb-13d951e68d25.mp4

pr_title: [GSoC] Fix sync button color
pr_body:
## Purpose / Description
If user changed themes, the sync icon would use the same color of the sync category icon

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/174460604-60f8fb7b-58ae-4641-9ccd-55e89a59fc40.png)


## Approach
Make sync icon inherit its color from `iconColor` attribute and set it to white on the top bar style.

More work could be done to untangle some icons from their colors and use styles to tint them instead of doing it programatically (e.g. on the reviewer app bar actions). I currently don't have time to untangle all the XMLs and icons, which should be a fair amount of work, but I particularly see it as an valid issue.

## How Has This Been Tested?

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69634269/174460499-e9d40a31-b445-41e6-b32f-45bd0d16c515.mp4

## Learning (optional, can help others)
TIL that setting the tint of an icon on code is a global change which will be shown if an activity is recreated.
